Award.AwardTitle: NSFSaTC-BSF: TWC: Small: Horizons of Symmetric-Key Cryptography

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Symmetric-key primitives are the lifeblood of practical cryptography, and are critical components of nearly any computer security system. The cryptographic community has developed a rich body of work on theoretically sound symmetric objects, but they are many orders of magnitude too slow for realistic usage. Thus, practitioners use fast primitives that have been designed to withstand known attacks, but which lack rigorous security guarantees based on natural mathematical problems. Recent results demonstrate that symmetric primitives based on theoretically sound designs can also enjoy realistic levels of efficiency. This project leverages this insight to demonstrate the feasibility, efficiency, and broad applicability of a wide array of new symmetric objects to enable new security applications.

The focus of this project is the design of theoretically sound and computationally efficient symmetric-key cryptographic schemes. These will range from basic primitives like pseudorandom functions and block ciphers; to applications like proof systems, digital signatures, functional encryption, and broadcast encryption, and will also include practical implementations such as fully homomorphic evaluation of symmetric-key primitives. A core theme of this research is to exploit the algebraic structure, and to demonstrate feasibility of symmetric-key objects in settings where public-key ones appear significantly more difficult (or impossible) to obtain. The project will also develop open-source software library that exhibits these constructions in practice, and facilitates further implementations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has yielded major theoretical and practical contributions that broaden the power and applicability of symmetric-key cryptography, both in its own right and in the context of public-key cryptography and encrypted computation (also known as homomorphic cryptography).

A sampling of the project's intellectual contributions are as follows:

  1. It constructed central tools of symmetric cryptography called pseudorandom functions (PRFs) that enjoy additional rich functionality, delegation, and privacy properties. These properties yield directly applications like searchable symmetric-key encryption and software watermarking, among others.
  2. It designed, implemented, and prototyped specialized programming languages and compilers that allow non-experts to more easily express and program encrypted computations. Using these tools, the project implemented the fastest and simplest encrypted computation of a PRF to date, improving the prior record of a few minutes down to just a few seconds (on a standard laptop). Such encrypted computations of symmetric-key cryptographic objects have many uses in homomorphic cryptography, e.g., dramatically reducing clients' computation and communication, and enabling arbitrary (unbounded) encrypted computations.
  3. It gave new protocols for proving various geometric properties of lattices, which are non-interactive and/or "zero knowledge" (i.e., they reveal nothing more than the relevant property itself). Such protocols have applications to cryptography, e.g., to prove that cryptographic keys are well-formed or that the claimed outputs of a symmetric-key algorithm are correct. Compared to previous protocols, the new ones prove that the relevant quantities lie in a much narrower range, which in turn cana be used to improve the efficiency and amount of communication required in applications.
  4. Finally, it strongly improved and generalized the provable hardness of the "Ring-LWE" problem, which sits at the foundation of countless efficient symmetric (and asymmetric) cryptographic schemes based on lattices. This result gives further understanding of, and confidence in, the security of Ring-LWE in its various potential incarnations.

The broader impacts of the project include the PI's detailed monograph surveying modern lattice-based cryptography, which includes coverage of symmetric-key primitives and advanced applications based on lattices. The survey has been published freely via the Internet, and is widely used in the PI's and others' graduate cryptography courses. As mentioned above, the project has also produced robust, general-purpose, freely available software tools and implementations to foster adoption and prototyping of advanced lattice-based cryptosystems. Finally, the project has supported research by several graduate and undergraduate students.
